section.title: Introduction
section.para: Provide a broad description of the runoff processes that contribute to streamflows, ie interception, depression storage, infiltration, interflow, and groundwater contributions. Identification of those components of most relevance to flood generation, which leads to following sections.

section.title: Runoff generation
section.para: Discussion of runoff generation processes, eg Hortonian overland flow, partial area runoff, saturation excess runoff, variable source areas, and subsurface storm flow, and link to simple loss models in Book 5 Chapter 5. Discuss difference in processes between urban and rural catchments.

section.title: Baseflow
section.para: Discussion of groundwater processes, and link to simple baseflow models presented in Book 5 Chapter 4.

section.title: Flow routing
section.para: Introduce different routing elements and different forms of storage (from hillslopes to streams, floodplains, natural and artificial storages). Discuss hydraulic basis (with link to relevant sections of Book 6) and simplified representation in hydrologic models (refer to Book 5). Also differences between natural waterways (rural catchments) and constructed drainage systems (urban catchments).

section.title: Case studies
section.para: Provide overview of case studies that illustrate runoff response to large rainfalls in an urban and rural catchments.
